com.poesys.db.dao.delete

Class AbstractDeleteSql<T extends IDbDto>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.poesys.db.dao.delete.AbstractDeleteSql<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the DTO type
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    IDeleteSql<T>

    public abstract class AbstractDeleteSql<T extends IDbDto>
extends java.lang.Object
implements IDeleteSql<T>
    SQL statement specification for deleting a standard object. The concrete subclass contains the SQL statement and an implementation of IDeleteSql.getSql() that calls the getSql method in this class: 
     public class DeleteTestSql extends AbstractDeleteSql {
 
   private static final String SQL = "DELETE FROM Test WHERE ";
 
   public String getSql(IPrimaryKey key) {
     return super.getSql(key, SQL);
   }
 }
    Author:
    Robert J. Muller

    • Method Detail

      • getSql

        public java.lang.String getSql(IPrimaryKey key,
                      java.lang.String sql)
        A helper method that takes the SQL from the caller (usually a concrete subclass of this class) and builds a complete SQL statement by adding the key to the WHERE clause
        Parameters:
        key - the primary key to add to the WHERE clause
        sql - the SQL statement
        Returns:
        a complete SQL statement

      • setParams

        public <P extends IDbDto> int setParams(java.sql.PreparedStatement stmt,
                               int next,
                               P dto)
              throws java.sql.SQLException
        Description copied from interface: IDeleteSql
        Set the primary key parameters of the DELETE statement.
        Specified by:
        setParams in interface IDeleteSql<T extends IDbDto>
        Type Parameters:
        P - the type of DTO containing parameters
        Parameters:
        stmt - the prepared SQL statement
        next - the next parameter index after the last parameter index set
        dto - the data transfer object of type T containing the primary key values to set into the statement
        Returns:
        the index of the next parameter to set (the first primary key value)
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - when the parameter setting fails with a SQL error
